> <@yulia:mozilla.org> shu: do we have an alternative facilitator?

I believe I should shadow a facilitator before I volunteer for that role, but if nobody steps up, I will definitely do my best impression. My understanding is that this mostly involves making sure agenda and minutes get captured, in addition to shepherding the meeting.

I’ve sketched an agenda:
1. Overflow from my kick-off on Module Harmony thru the Compartments lens
2. nicolo-ribaudo on Module Harmony thru the lens of Module Blocks’s emerging spec text
3. caridy on minimum-viable first-class Module and ModuleSource

content.body: I believe yulia | Out of Office until July 11th had in mind some important front-matter to get us all on the same page for each other’s hopes and expectations from module harmony, which I think we ought to pursue as early as possible. I can also attempt to facilitate that, though I’m also not confident I can fill Yulia’s shoes.

content.body: I mean that module maps are currently implied into existence by 262, through host behaviors. There isn’t a [[ModuleMap]], say, on a Realm record. (Qualifier: this is hearsay. I’m not sufficiently intimate with 262 to purport the non-existence of anything within its pages.)

content.body: Caridy’s driving toward a simplification of the compartment proposal that notably omits Compartment. I’m convinced that it’s functionally equivalent, even up to preserving all useful idempotence invariants and compatibility with our hardened JavaScript objectives. Omitting compartments effectively moves all module memoization behavior to a new kind of concrete Module Record, say, Virtual Module Record, which would be reïfied by a `new Module` constructor.

content.body: My opinion is that, to use the name `Module`, it must be exceedingly worthy. That is to say, there must never come a time in the evolution of 262 that we reify an object that is worthier of the title or create a class where this particular kind of module is no more special that the others. I believe it meets that criterion iff it turns out that all specialization of modules going forward is sufficiently addressed with new types of Static Module Record.

content.body: Yes, it's the most confusing name possible

Assuming `new Module(source, importHook, importMeta)` is sufficient, `importMeta` is _not_ identical to `import.meta` as seen by the source, but _is_ identical to the object received by `importHook` to address the referrer, as in `importHook(importSpecifier, importMeta) => Promise<Module>`.
content.formatted_body: Assuming new Module(source, importHook, importMeta) is sufficient, importMeta is not identical to import.meta as seen by the source, but is identical to the object received by importHook to address the referrer, as in importHook(importSpecifier, importMeta) => Promise<Module>.

content.body: What i’m saying is that, for the purposes of this side table, importMeta as given to the constructor may be copied over an Object with a null prototype and all useful properties of import hooks are preserved.

content.body: I’m not saying that they can’t be identical. It probably wouldn’t be useful to create a new mechanism that allows `import.meta` to be a number or a proxy.

content.body: One way to do that would be copying properties. Another would just be to assert its nature. Asserting it’s not a proxy is somewhat hard.

content.body:
> <@littledan:matrix.org> hmm, why?

Continuity with the past. The alternative is to suggest that this virtualization be limited to situations where `import.meta.url`, `import.meta.resolve`, or some other property carries the referrer in another host-defined sort of way. Not all existing environments meet that bar. I’m not suggesting this is a blocker. I’m suggesting that it’s definitely not a blocker. Those environments can be emulated with a side table keyed on `importMeta`, regardless of whether that’s identical to `import.meta`.

content.body: Which is to say, the problem I imagined with not enshrining `referrer` in the `Module` constructor, turns out to be imaginary.

content.body: But isn't `import.meta` lazily-initialized (on first access), so potentially not available when transferring a module block?
content.formatted_body: But isn't import.meta lazily-initialized (on first access), so potentially not available when transferring a module block?

org.matrix.msc1767.message.body: But isn't `import.meta` lazily-initialized (on first access), so potentially not available when transferring a module block?
But isn't import.meta lazily-initialized (on first access), so potentially not available when transferring a module block?

content.body: As written today, yes.
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: As written today, yes.

content.body: Lazy initialization of `import.meta` could be copying properties from `importMeta`.
content.formatted_body: Lazy initialization of import.meta could be copying properties from importMeta.

org.matrix.msc1767.message.body: Lazy initialization of `import.meta` could be copying properties from `importMeta`.
Lazy initialization of import.meta could be copying properties from importMeta.

content.body: Regardless, if we relaxed the verbiage around lazy initialization of `import.meta`, the change wouldn’t be observable.
content.formatted_body: Regardless, if we relaxed the verbiage around lazy initialization of import.meta, the change wouldn’t be observable.

org.matrix.msc1767.message.body: Regardless, if we relaxed the verbiage around lazy initialization of `import.meta`, the change wouldn’t be observable.
Regardless, if we relaxed the verbiage around lazy initialization of import.meta, the change wouldn’t be observable.

content.body: Bradley related to us at a SES call of yore that Node.js depends on this laziness to avoid instantiating an `import.meta.resolve` closure for every module. That gets created lazily on the first evaluation of `import.meta`. In the Compartments proposal, we solved that problem by adding a `needsImportMeta` property to `ModuleSource / StaticModuleRecord` instances such that a `loadHook / importHook` can avoid building an `importMeta` except for modules that are likely to need it, by reflecting static analysis.
content.formatted_body: Bradley related to us at a SES call of yore that Node.js depends on this laziness to avoid instantiating an import.meta.resolve closure for every module. That gets created lazily on the first evaluation of import.meta. In the Compartments proposal, we solved that problem by adding a needsImportMeta property to ModuleSource / StaticModuleRecord instances such that a loadHook / importHook can avoid building an importMeta except for modules that are likely to need it, by reflecting static analysis.

org.matrix.msc1767.message.body: Bradley related to us at a SES call of yore that Node.js depends on this laziness to avoid instantiating an `import.meta.resolve` closure for every module. That gets created lazily on the first evaluation of `import.meta`. In the Compartments proposal, we solved that problem by adding a `needsImportMeta` property to `ModuleSource / StaticModuleRecord` instances such that a `loadHook / importHook` can avoid building an `importMeta` except for modules that are likely to need it, by reflecting static analysis.

Bradley related to us at a SES call of yore that Node.js depends on this laziness to avoid instantiating an import.meta.resolve closure for every module. That gets created lazily on the first evaluation of import.meta. In the Compartments proposal, we solved that problem by adding a needsImportMeta property to ModuleSource / StaticModuleRecord instances such that a loadHook / importHook can avoid building an importMeta except for modules that are likely to need it, by reflecting static analysis.

content.body: Caridy’s direction preserves that solution.
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: Caridy’s direction preserves that solution.
